title: Replace lazy_static dependency in chain crate with once_cell
body:
~~Addresses #213~~

This PR replaces usage of the `lazy_static!` macro with the `once_cell::sync::Lazy` type. This accomplishes the same goals as `lazy_static!` by [lazily initializing global data](https://docs.rs/once_cell/1.9.0/once_cell/#lazy-initialized-global-data). `once_cell` has the following advantages over `lazy_static`:
* `once_cell` has seen more recent active development
  * [once_cell = "1.9.0"](https://crates.io/crates/once_cell/1.9.0) was released about 1 month ago
  * [lazy_static = "1.4.0"](https://crates.io/crates/lazy_static/1.4.0) was released over 2 years ago
* `once_cell` functionality is in the current nightly build of Rust - [tracking issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/74465)

Other comparisons between the two libraries
* All-time downloads (according to crates.io):
  * [once_cell](https://crates.io/crates/once_cell) = ~40 million 
  * [lazy_static](https://crates.io/crates/lazy_static) = ~70 million
* Github contributors/stars
  * [once_cell](https://github.com/matklad/once_cell) = 34 contributors, 931 stars
  * [lazy_static](https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/lazy-static.rs) = 47 contributors, 1.3k stars

body:
Completes #79. Without message handlings

Problem:
This PR is causing the following error in my local
```
   Compiling lnpbp v0.3.0-alpha.1 (/home/raj/github-repo/rust-lnpbp)
error[E0277]: `(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)` cannot be sent between threads safely
  --> src/lnp/application/message.rs:35:1
   |
35 | / lazy_static! {
36 | |     pub static ref LNPWP_UNMARSHALLER: Unmarshaller<Messages> =
37 | |         Messages::create_unmarshaller();
38 | | }
   | |_^ `(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)` cannot be sent between threads safely
   | 
  ::: /home/raj/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/lazy_static-1.4.0/src/inline_lazy.rs:19:20
   |
19 |   pub struct Lazy<T: Sync>(Cell<Option<T>>, Once);
   |                      ---- required by this bound in `lazy_static::lazy::Lazy`
   |
   = help: the trait `Send` is not implemented for `(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)`
   = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `Sync` for `Arc<(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)>`
   = note: required because of the requirements on the impl of `Sync` for `amplify::alloc::collections::btree::node::Root<tlv::Type, Arc<(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)>>`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `Option<amplify::alloc::collections::btree::node::Root<tlv::Type, Arc<(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)>>>`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `std::collections::BTreeMap<tlv::Type, Arc<(dyn std::any::Any + 'static)>>`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `Stream`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `QueryShortChannelIds`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `Messages`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `PhantomData<Messages>`
   = note: required because it appears within the type `payload::Unmarshaller<Messages>`
   = note: this error originates in a macro (in Nightly builds, run with -Z macro-backtrace for more info)
 ```
 
 Can probably be a rust issue. This specific part of the code throwing the error is not being touched here.

title: [WIP] Implementing HTLC extension modification to TxGraph

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

milestone.title: v0.3.0
milestone.description:
- Support of Miniscript 4
- Split into multiple crates (internet2, client_side_validation, bp, lnp, rgb)

body:
This is a WIP on HTLC extension modification to the TXGraph structure. 

This is preliminary and for approach check. There are many rough edges. Instead of describing the issues here, I have added comments in the codebase referring to which discussions can be held here. 

There are many data that are required for constructing these HTLC transactions which are not there in the HTLC structure. I suppose the extension would then need to have access to global channel state variables in order to get that information. Suggestions over this would be helpful.

This might be also a good time to decide how these should be stored on the graph map inside TxGraph.
 
Note: for anchor outputs, we would need clear segregation Anchors, HTLCs, and payment outputs of a commitment Tx. There will be specific modifications on specific outputs. We should think of creating the TxGraph keeping that in mind.

title: add publish testing workflow
body:
this PR adds a "Publish" workflow to catch early issues that may arise at publishing time

as briefly discussed, if this introduces a significant slowdown in day to day operations, we can wait to merge this or devise a new scheme to handle code contributions (and contributors) that require the least friction

notes:
- `cargo publish` is called with the `--dry-run` option to skip the real publishing
- a first fix that's been found by the workflow is included (`error: all dependencies must have a version specified when publishing.`)

title: Implement Noise Handshake (BOLT8)

milestone.title: v0.2.0
milestone.description: Complete LNP implementation (lightning network protocol)

body:
This implements the Noise handshake protocol as per BOLT8 as per [Issue134](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/issues/134). This PR mostly uses the BOLT8 handshake structures implemented [here](https://github.com/rust-bitcoin/rust-lightning/pull/691), which is refactored to suit our needs. 

Following are brief descriptions of modules in `src/lnp/session/noise/` directory

`act`: This describes the handshake action structures as defined in BOLT8.\
`chacha`: Encryption and Decryption functions for ChaCha20Poly1305 AEAD encryption.
`hkdf`: Key derivation functions as defined in BOLT8
`conduit`: Connection conduit that has read buffer and implements automatic key rotation as per BOLT8. This structure is also implemented with `Transcode` and `Bipolar` to make the API compatible with other parts of the library.
`handshake`: The Handshake states and their transition logic as per BOLT8.

This is more or less self contained at this moment. The Noise module is private and none of the functionalities are used elsewhere.

A previous `noise.rs` file which had basic AEAD examples has been removed. 

Test cases are included to indicate the proper functioning of the module.

Open to suggestion on how to properly credit the above PR author in rust-lightning.

title: Release v0.1

labels.name: epic
labels.description: Large or meta-issues with multiple related issues and tasks

milestone.title: v0.1.0 Release
milestone.description: Peer-reviewed initial release with test coverage >66%

body:
## Major changes since RC2
- Support for Rust stable and MSRV reduction to 1.41.1
- Custom forks for upstream bitcoin-related dependencies are changed onto the
  latest publicly-released versions

## Breaking changes since RC2
- Updated taproot-based hashed tag system (BIP-340) according to the most
  recent specs.
- RGB `Amount` renamed into `AtomicValue`
- RGB `amount` mod renamed into `value`
- RGB seal definitions and related structures are now `Copy` and returned by 
  value

title: Refactoring bp::Network into Chain and ChainParams: closes #102

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

milestone.title: v0.2.0
milestone.description: Complete LNP implementation (lightning network protocol)

body: Lightning network supports multiple chains, so bitcoin mainnet, testnet, signet, liquid and even non-bitcoin litecoin are part of the same network. Because of this LN uses chain hash - and LN nodes internally define a set of chain parameters to operate with different networks. In order to be interoperable with this concept, and in order to increase Liquid compatibility this PR implements generic concept of Chains and ChainParams as a part of `bp` mod (bitcoin protocol) and moves RGB from using just a P2P network magic bytes in Schema to encoding complete chain parameter data as a part of asset genesis (restricting commitment only to the chain genesis block hash). See attached issues for more details: #102, #100 & #95, as well as https://github.com/LNP-BP/LNPBPs/issues/58

title: Add test coverage to assignments

labels.name: test
labels.description: Improvements to test coverage and CI

body:
This adds test coverage for `AssignmentVariant` structure.
Estimated coverage 78%.

Note

- This depends on [this fix](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/pull/67#issuecomment-685867562) to be applied on `AssignmentsVariant::zero_balanced()`. For now the test logic is reversed here.
```
// Check sum verification of commitments
        assert_eq!(
            amount::Confidential::verify_commit_sum(positve, negative),
            false
        );
```
`verify_commit_sum()` should return true once `zero_balanced()` is fixed. Wrong values are not tested here as it has already been covered in test cases for `Ammount` structures.

- This huge structure `PEDERSAN_VARIANT` is this big because of the confidential amounts. Each variant type contains 4 types of assignments, `Revealed`, `Confidential`, `ConfidentialSeal`, `ConfidentialAmount`. As each confidential amount is 712 bytes as encoded data, a pedersan type assignment variant with all 4 types of assignments becomes quite large.

Also let me know if any more test cases to be added.

title: Fixes build failure due to rust-1.47.0 update
body:
This solves rgb-node [Issue#29](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rgb-node/issues/29)

The compilation error was due to rust-nightly update to version 1.47.0.

Build passes except a test which should pass after updating the test data.
```
failures:

---- rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation stdout ----
```

title: Use 32-bit integers for transaction output indexes in single-use seals

milestone.title: v0.1.0 Beta 3
milestone.description: Test coverage >50%

body:
This solves [Issue#45](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/issues/45)

The change is fairly trivial unless I am missing something.

Build + Tests passes.

title: Added Support for Tor V2

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

milestone.title: v0.1.0 Release
milestone.description: Peer-reviewed initial release with test coverage >66%

body:
Minimal Tor Onion V2 address support has been implemented as per [Issue#29](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/issues/29)

Due to upstream incompatibility, for now, `OnionAddressV2` can only be constructed from an address string and not from a byte array, unlike other `InetAddr` variants.

`OnionAddressV2` Doesn't implement Copy, thus Copy derivation has been removed from `InteAddr` which causes change in some other part of the libraries which is bundled in the last commit.

The library compiles and unit tests passing.

Note: I haven't tried rust-rgb to see if anything breaks there because of removing Copy Dervitation, will check later and update.

title: Changes Blinding factor from 32 bit to 64 bit.

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

milestone.title: v0.1.0 Beta 3
milestone.description: Test coverage >50%

body:
Changes the blinding factor from 32 bit to 64 bit as suggested by [Issue#51](https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/issues/51)

- Full build compiled
- one test failure with `all` features at 
```
test rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation ... FAILED
failures:

---- rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation stdout ----
thread 'rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: UnsupportedDataStructure("We support only homomorphic commitments to U64 data")', src/rgb/stash/consignment.rs:124:47
```
With the following backtrace
```
13: core::panicking::panic_fmt
             at src/libcore/panicking.rs:85
  14: core::option::expect_none_failed
             at src/libcore/option.rs:1269
  15: core::result::Result<T,E>::unwrap
             at /home/raj/.rustup/toolchains/nightly-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/rustlib/src/rust/src/libcore/result.rs:1005
  16: lnpbp::rgb::stash::consignment::test::consignment
             at src/rgb/stash/consignment.rs:124
  17: lnpbp::rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation
             at src/rgb/stash/consignment.rs:136
  18: lnpbp::rgb::stash::consignment::test::test_consignment_validation::{{closure}}
             at src/rgb/stash/consignment.rs:135
  19: core::ops::function::FnOnce::call_once
             at /home/raj/.rustup/toolchains/nightly-x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu/lib/rustlib/src/rust/src/libcore/ops/function.rs:233
```
I can't seem to identify the source of the decoding error. My guess is this raw consignment data needs to be modified with 64-bit blinds.  
https://github.com/LNP-BP/rust-lnpbp/blob/2f6fee732417aad5c71fcd0120ed0db4b1e61061/src/rgb/stash/consignment.rs#L95-L98



- As I was already touching the `src/bp/strict_encoding.rs`, I have slid in another small change that fixes a buffer misallocation bug. It seemed obvious to me that the signature read buffer size was wrong, but not sure why it wasn't causing any upstream failure. If I am missing something and it was supposed to be what it was, will revert the commit.

title: Various fixes
body:
* Fixes again the blinding factors generation
* Changes TxResolver to be a Trait so that we can use a complex struct as a resolver. It's useful if the resolver has some internal state that can be reused, like a connection to an Electrum server or a Bitcoin Core RPC.

title: ElGamal encryption

labels.name: enhancement

body: According to https://crypto.stackexchange.com/a/45042, for such use cases as http://gnusha.org/bitcoin-wizards/2020-06-11.log (search for ElGamal)

title: Avoid using private dependency of lightning crate
body:
The secp256k1 dependency is not declared as public, yet this crate
depended on it. This was preiously accepted by the compiler, but it's
disabled in the newest versions.

This change uses the `secp256k1` crate directly instead.

It might be actually better for `rust-lightning` to reexport the module or some types, but I will need to take some time to write a coherent explanation why that's a good thing.

FYI This is a part of attempt to update to the newer version of lightning in order to test if link problems were solved.

title: EPIC: Grand library refactoring and revising

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

body:
- [x] refactor module structure
- [x] introduce proper interface abstractions with primitives
     - [x] single-use seals
     - [ ] client-side validation
     - [x] strict serialization
     - [x] more straightforward commit-verify and commit-embed primitives
- [x] upgrade common components (like `Wrapper`, `AsSlice`) to use more idiomatic rust code
- [x] upgrade all parts to the modern syntax
- [x] use rustfmt
- [x] avoid using wildcard imports
- [x] check the code against LNPBP standards
- [x] write doc comments
- [x] do a test coverage
- [ ] new verification & validation workflow
- [x] new RGB entity architecture

title: Refactoring network enum to support open set of networks

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

title: Making RGB-1 (fungible assets) amounts u64-based
body:
This is required for compatibility with Liquid confidential assets,
which are using 64-bit amounts.

256-bit amounts were introduced into RGB-1 as an attempt to avoid
use of sized rangeproofs for confidential amounts; however after
conversation with Peter Wuille it became apparent that 256-bit
amounts will still require range proofs; however the change of
64->256 bit standard never happened back. This commit solves
this issue.

Related issues: #38

title: Functions required for full wallet support

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: Improvement to existing functionality or refactoring

title: Implemented serde support for InetAddr
body:
This implements optional `serde` support, so far only for InetAddr. It'd
be nice to implement it for other things, but this is minimum
requirement for implementing `configure_me`.

~~Unresolved question: should we defer to the default implementation or
redirect it to `FromStr`, so that the values in config files are nicer?~~

I decided to go with stringly serialization because arguments use it too and it'd be weird to write `nodeaddr@host:port` on command line, but something like:

```
[[connect]]
pubkey: "..."
host: "..."
port: 9735
```

in the config.

As an alternative we could support the format above as an alternative form of deserialization, but I suggest to put this off until someone actually needs it. There are more important things to do now.

title: rgb: make txid optional to allow pointing back to the committing tx
body:
Without this it would be impossibile to point to one of the outputs created by the committing transaction
because the txid is not known until the commitments are actually placed in the transaction.

title: Remove the `hex` unused dependency
body: It looks like it has already been replaced with the one provided by `bitcoin_hashes`.
